column4: anyone have suggestions for how i can track why my I/O wait is so high?
i/o on the hard drive'll be something you can look at with hdparm.
i'm pretty sure it's harddrive-related actually, because my system is running on a compact flashcard that's in PIO mode.  however, it happens while streaming a movie over my network ... so ...
i'm trying to see if mplayer is thinking it will outsmart me by caching the movie
you said it was i/o related. Is it that or your network, then? What made you think i/o? Just a guess? guesses are okay, I'm just trying to make sure I understand.
i've only ever seen "wait" be high in top when it was waiting on I/O
inar
read man top.
aw, that's a pretty official rtfm :(
it tells you what all the WAIT and whatnot mean. Either that or man ps.
ok, and it says it's I/O
so it's either network latency or disk latency, and i'd like to know how to tell which one
I don't tell *everyone*to read man pages. Only people who're sounding like they already have some undersatnding and are interested ;
they're dense information, and really awesome.
i know, i was just pretty sure of myself with it
think of man pages as secret unix knowledge going back forty, fifty years. They're the awesome.
i use man a lot
heh
actually, in my terminal right now, 3 of my 4 tabs are manpages
okay, you can either benchmark your network or your latency. BUt here's a freebie: if you have solid state storage, and you're streaming a movie over the network, it's almost certainly network.
generally, you'd think so, but solid state != fast in this case :(
solid state in this context just means no moving parts
try rsyncing a file with the --progress flag, that'll help.
